instructions: Sort the statements into the grid based on how much you agree or disagree.

statements.text: I would buy Baba Nyonya-inspired items if they are modernized and easier to wear.
Knowing the meaning behind motifs like the phoenix or peony makes Baba Nyonya designs more meaningful.
Modern renovations that ignore heritage guidelines threaten the authenticity of Baba Nyonya neighborhoods.
Too many traditional patterns in one space can feel visually overwhelming
Traditional decorations with rich colors bring joy to the environment.
I think Baba Nyonya tiles are too complicated for modern interior design.
I'm more attracted to traditional decor when it is mixed with modern styles.
While I appreciate the craftsmanship, I wouldn’t use it in my own space.
I prefer minimalist designs; traditional elements often make a space feel cluttered.
Baba Nyonya culture is undervalued because it is not promoted enough in modern media and design.
More organizations should support Baba Nyonya art and fashion to preserve the culture.
Peranakan identity is hybrid and ever-evolving, not fixed in time.
Cultural mixing—not dilution—defines the uniqueness and vitality of Baba Nyonya heritage.
We should celebrate ‘orphan’ or ‘bastard’ artifacts that don’t fit standard cultural narratives.
Some people see using historical decor as a form of cultural performance rather than genuine identity.
Strict preservation of heritage buildings helps maintain a meaningful cultural environment.
Antique decor from our grandparents carries our cultural memories.
Peranakan-style elements make me reflect on my Chinese heritage.
Inconsistent guidelines between heritage cities weaken efforts to protect shared cultural identity.
Cultural tourism can flourish only when historical integrity is properly safeguarded.
Young people today are not very familiar with Baba Nyonya traditional fashion and design.
Handcrafted Baba Nyonya items are difficult to sell online because of sizing and fit issues.
Products inspired by Baba Nyonya culture are too expensive for everyday consumers.
I would recommend others to incorporate Baba Nyonya decor in their homes.
I feel Baba Nyonya decor is only suitable for cultural events, not everyday life.
